title: Leapfrog Creatr nozzle cooling system V2

description.text:
Hi all! Because certain issues when printing bridges and problematic areas with my Leapfrog Creatr I decided to design a colling system for the printerÃÂ´s nozzle.
An add on is the increased printing speed. I needed about 6 versions (someones with sub-versions) but finally IÃÂ´m happy with this final design.
This design can use a 50x50mm fan or a 60x60mm one, IÃÂ´ll suggest a 50x50mm one (easy to find over ebay, I bought this one "Delta AUB0512HB 50x50x15mm 5015 DC 12V 0.15A Brushless Fan 2-pin 2510 Connector"), but there is a choice to use a 60x60mm kind, but it will crash a little with the right rear stepper. I also added in both sides holes to insert a couple of 5mm leds so we can see better the printing area :D
Instructions are pretty simple, just print it all, do some cleaning and mount it with a few bolts.

title: Daft Punk Guy Manuel 3D Printable Wearable Helmet

description.text:
If you like this design, buy me a beer :)
http://www.thingiverse.com/bendiger/about UPDATE 09-17-16
Thanks to all the hard work of Nathan720 (http://www.thingiverse.com/Nathan720), there is now an instructables post for how to build the helmets!
http://www.instructables.com/id/Two-Daft-Punk-Helmets-in-One-Month/ It's what everyone has been waiting for!
The Daft Punk Guy Manuel 3D Printable helmet for small printers!
All the parts are for the left side and just need to be mirrored to print the right. Set the X scale to -1
This design is for small 3D Printers with print beds 6x6in or bigger.
All parts Zip tie or glue together.
Support Material is a must for most parts. These are not optimized for supportless printing due to there shape.
About 60 hours of printing so far, and 1 reels of 3mm abs.
It will be compatible with the AlexPlusLEDs fans and chin lights which can be found here: http://alexplusleds.bigcartel.com/
STL files are orientated for printing on a 6x6 bed.
The visor mold that will soon be included can be used to make your own clear visor form for vacuum forming.
Want the Thomas Bangalter Helmet? Here it is:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:338831
---UPDATES---
06-27-15 Well, I should have updated this a while back. All the files are updated and scaled to match the Thomas Helmet. Hopefully they look good and work better size wise.
10-16-14 I uploaded a quick Back Wire Harness for the wires on the back of the head. Its simple and will be updated to have groves to hold the wires in place.
10-04-14 I've uploaded the visor mold and the support parts. All parts should be mirrored and glued together very well to handle vacuum forming. I suggest a good thick coat of epoxy or bondo on the inside of the mold to avoid cracking during forming. Please let me know if there are any problems with slicing, some of the parts were a rush job and didn't need to look pretty.
Also, I have uploaded the ear cups and side panels. The ear cup is not ready for electronics, it was uploaded because of a request.

Thanks to all the hard work of Nathan720 (http://www.thingiverse.com/Nathan720), there is now an instructables post for how to build the helmets!
http://www.instructables.com/id/Two-Daft-Punk-Helmets-in-One-Month/ All parts need to be mirrored for the right side. All parts should print on a 6x6 bed. The fans don't need support material.

comments.text: I made mine with ABS, It was easy to "weld" together and smooth. Most of the parts I designed should be small enough to not warp, but some of then do have some issues. It's not really that big a deal in the big picture, as filler of some kind is needed to fill the cracks. PLA can't be welded very well. Most two part epoxies wont work well, and it's more brittle. Check out Instructables for Vacuum forming machines. Very simple to make and well worth it for other projects.

Some users below have had luck scaling it down, but keep in mind the electronic mounts wont fit after words. as for the print lines... a lot of sanding... a lot... get a lot of sandpaper. If you're not good at spray painting, do three.

description.text: A model of a normal guitar
Made in Maya 2012 and exported through Blender.

Nice compact fan 80mm x 80mm fan holder.
Helps clean up cables and cool down your board.
Easy to mount. Easy and fast to print.

It's pretty simple, four parts, The cap gets printed twice, The rings once, and the Maker once. It makes burger making easy! Parts come apart for easy cleaning.
Print the parts at different sizes to get different size burgers. X and Y for size and Z for thickness.
Print these in HIPS Plastic! It is food grade and safe for the dishwasher. ABS and PLA are a bad idea. HIPS is roughly the same price as ABS and PLA and will print the same.
Takes about 12hours total to print at 100 microns. Smoothing the insides where the meat touches the plastic is recommended.

Just place a ball of meat on the bottom plate with the ring on top of it. Grease the plunger/maker and then press the it into the meat and remove. This is were the fillings go. Now fill the cavity with whatever you want in your burger, then place a flat disk of meat on top and use the second Cap plate to press the meet together. Add extra meat as needed to fill the mold Remove the plate from the top and bottom and push the Jucy Lucy out of the ring carefully.
Bam, Jucy Lucy Burger!

description.text: These are removable prescription eyeglass lens holders for the current DK2 (MUST BE USED WITH THE DK2'S "B" LENSES). In honour of Thingiverse Thursday here's a design that has been sitting on our hard drive for a little while. Its a simple little box that makes wiring up an 8 x 8 LED Matrix easy. It uses the MAX7219 (or 7221) LED driver chip from Maxim and uses the Matrix library in the Arduino library. For Details on how to wire up and program try:
http://www.arduino.cc/playground/Main/MAX72XXHardware A small video of it scrolling a Valentines day message:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/snazzyguy/3277618701

Cutting
Cut from any 3mm stock. (Cut-Black, Engrave-Blue, Ignore-others) Assembly
A few 3mm x 10mm screws, and some soldering. Wiring
Download the breadboard layout sheet pdf. Print it (important do not scale). Follow the guidelines and connect it to an Arduino. Programming
Try out the demo programs in the Arduino IDE. Or for scrolling messages you can use the program we wrote (it is quite clunky and may need a little tweaking) (downloadable below). We hope you enjoy and if you have any questions or need any help we'll try our best on [email protected] )

description.text:
This is a calibration comb test for your makerbot.  Make sure you're laying down nice parallel and evenly spaced lines.  Rotate 90 degrees to test both x and y axes.  Use the included .scad file to create calibration tests large enough for your entire platform if you're a real stickler for precision!
This is also meant to be a base for an ooze test... I'm hoping some enterprising individual will want to add the test to the end of each line.  The extra commands needed are to stop the extruder, and move the bot at the feedrate (not travel feedrate) to the edge of the comb area - the end of the top-most string with the y coordinate modified for each line.  If you do, please post as derivative object.

Slice and print.  Use OpenSCAD and the included .scad file to adjust the carve sizes of the various pieces for your settings.
Using digital calipers, measure the spacing of all the lines and the length of each line.
In the included .stl files, the ruler edge (the bump at the left of the calibration lines) is 4 mm long.  Each line is 1mm longer than the previous.

description.text:
My first design, a small die in a larger die box with a working snap-fit hinge. Both dice are usable - even with one inside the other - but no guarantees about randomness.
Made to print with PLA in high resolution on e.g. a Replicator 2. 
Created in Autodesks interesting (and free for now) Inventor Fusion.

This is a pretty small thing considering the working hinge - it probably has to be printed at 0.1 mm resolution (this is what I did) - or be scaled up a bit. 
Update: Uploaded a slightly smaller inner die to make the die box close completely.

author: Slomp

description.text: My first ever designed 3D model! I tried many CAD CAM programs but Tinkercad did it me. This is a cover  for an Australian bathroom drain with bajonet locking so not sure if it has the right dimensions for other countries. Unfortunately our hardware stores don't sell fully closed ones and I really hate the smell of dried up water. The lid has a little round indented circle to allow you to close/open the lid. Enjoy!

Use the online Tinkercad tool to design it (www.tinkercad.com). Printed on a REPRAP Prusa Iteration 2. 1.75mm filament, 0.3mm, PLA black, 40% fill in and use support. It prints in an hour on my printer.

Tablet and Phone Stand smiling - designed by 3Dcpi
Find us at: www.3dcpi.com
Made in PLA, without raft or supports -  210ºC for extruder at 0,3mm for layer and 70ºC for hot platform, and 30mm for the speed.

comments.text: Made this, nice and simple but effective, good design, functional. Thanks
comments.author: chirop1

description.text:
Struggled to find a good gimbal for my Mobius action camera, so I decided to create my own.
The gimbal is probably not perfect but it´s pretty mutch in balance and working great on the bench.
It has been designed for minimal use of tools and bolts
The gimbal is built for 2208 motors and 50x50 gimbal controllers.
Clamps made for 12mm carbon rods with 58mm center-center.
I added the Skechup file for you to edit to you setup.

Printed on XYZ 3d printer.
Layer Hight: 0.2mm
3D density: 50%
Shells: Thick
Speed: Standard
Support density: Low

comments.text: Nice design but I have a question.  Since the whole assembly hangs off of the top plate through the 3rd axis (pan) motor.  Why is there even a bottom plat?  Would it be better to move the posts to the top plate that mounts to your carbon fiber mounts?
comments.author: Flyer007

comments.text:
Hi, that is a good question!
The reason I did this was because the extra axis increases the weight of the assembly, and I didn't trust the rubber dampers to hold my gimbal, also I thought that with the extra weight in mind it would give an extra vibration damping if compressing the rubber dampers rather then stretching them!
If you attach the upper plate to your carbon frame, you get no vibration damping from the copter..
But the sketchup files are there for you to alter the design so it fits your setup!
Have fun :-)
comments.author: Flyer007

comments.text: Okay that makes sense and is an interesting design concept (the compression).  I just didn't see it at first since the model render didn't have the anti vibration pieces in place.
comments.author: sneipen

comments.text: Very nice looking. I have to ask though..... What is the square plate with the hole in it on the upper bracket for? I would assume an FPV camera to see the view of the Mobius? would this mean you use two FPV cameras? I ask because typically you want your FPV cam to have a fixed position unless you're using head tracking.
comments.author: helifrek

comments.text:
Thank you! The plate with the holes in it is intended for the gimbal controller, like the evvgc controller.
The gimbal is only ment for one camera, you can set the gimbal to follow face of copter, that way it smooths out the small turn inputs on the copter, but follows when you are rotating..
Sorry for my poor english!

title: Imperial (SAE) Prusa Mendel Production Plates for Makerbot

description.text: The SAE variation of the Prusa Mendel is in a constant state of development, and that being true, Thingiverse is not the appropriate places to hold these files. Please go directly to the prusa mendel github at: https://github.com/prusajr/PrusaMendel I strongly suggest you follow the calibration routine Prusajr describes in this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kwQzp2hvcBI This will insure that your fasteners will fit correctly.

The overal instructions for Prusa Mendel are mostly static, but details change as you and others find new and better ways to do things. The instructions to construct both the metric and imperial instruction are at: http://reprap.org/wiki/Prusa_Mendel Some SAE specific instructions, such as a purchasing guide and rod cutting guide can be found here: http://reprap.org/wiki/SAE_Prusa_Mendel Any updates to the wiki should be done into the main Prusa site unless they are only relevant to SAE fasteners, in which case they should be done to the SAE page

title: Gmixer for Cura:  A program mixes gcode files with different layer settings

description.text:
• Gmixer-2.0.py can run on Windows, Mac and Linux now. Comment here if you have a problem.
  • Make sure around the cut height, the two to be mixed gcode files has one layer is on same height. Usually, you need to set the bottom layer of all sliced gcode files to same height .

    What does Gmixer do?

  • This python script mixes different gcode files to generate a new one with different settings (infill, layer heights, etc) for different layers (It’s like DNA crossover.). The current version Cura does not have this function. With proper settings of infill and layer heights for different layers, you can save a lot of time and get a very good printing at the same time.
  • This program has no GUI, so it’s not very user friendly. Everyone can use or edit my code freely. I have not enough time to improve it. I hope someone will. I hope someday the Cura developers will add this function.

    Installation:

  • Python 2.7.x, download link: https://www.python.org/downloads/
  • I have only tested it on Windows. Gmixer-2.0.py should be compatible with Mac and Linux now. But not tested with the 3D printer.
  • Only compatible with Cura generated gcode file!

    Use:

  • Step 1. Slicing stl model with different settings (infill, layer heights, etc);
  • Step 2. Edit configuration file;
  • Step 3. Generate mixed gcode file.

    Please read GmixerUserGuide.pdf for more details.

author: carbo

description.text:
I've done some playing with the openscad basics and found that the extrude function is pretty limited when it comes to more complex shape creation.
This is generated using mathematically generated 3D coordinates in a list and then picking off the values into a base, layers of paired triangles around the circumference and then a top, triangles from the perimeter to the centre. Each triangle is supposed to be drawn clockwise looking at the outside, do it the wrong way and in "thrown together" mode offending triangles will show as purple. I have it all showing correctly, but the stl rendering gives a non "simple" result.
Anyway, slic3r flags an error and won't slice it.
mattercontrol slices and prints it fine. See the instructions tab for successful printing. The key to a tidy wall and good sealing is to print considerably thicker than the nozzle orifice diameter by simulating a fatter diameter nozzle. This makes base printing much faster and means multiple walls aren't necessary.

3 bottom layers,
NO TOP LAYER,
0.5mm layer height
Change nozzle diameter setting to1.5mm to squeeze a fat watertight trail.
Slow feed rate down, I'm successfully using 25mm/sec. It still builds really nicely, watch your filament, it will feed faster due to the simulated large nozzle diameter. Geared extruder required.
Extruder 200 deg C to help the high filament feed rate.
Heated base 55 deg C and 40mm/sec outer layer.
Avoid crossing perimeters=on
spiral vase=on
2 outside layers.
I used Matter control with no issues.
Set fill off unless you want it solid! :-)

title: slim pulley system for qubd one up two up

description.text:
A small pulley system, mod, for the one up two up 3d printers.
Very quick print, you will need two of the top pulleys, and one bottom.
This has no moving parts, so not technically a pulley, but more a cable guide.
One small hole will have to be drilled into side of mdf housing for lower pulley, and a longer m3 bolt will be needed to reach the stepper motor threads on top, just a few mm longer.

when installing, attach cable to z rod brass coupler screw, around and to the gantry on opposite side.
works with my filament guide.
tightening the screw in drilled hole, will tighten the system, and makes it slightly adjustable.
I used a coated cable from a scanner, so there wouldn't be any stretch, but a heavy strong fishing line would probably work since the z axis moves so slowly, there should be very little heat or wear.

comments.text:
Hi, what kind of fire did you use ?
I printed yours but I can't find the right wire combination, spectra 0.5 mm flexes, I have some metal wire but not sure if it's good enough
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text:
I had a few old mustek scanners laying around and tore them open. I found some steel cables inside, that had a thick clear plastic coating on them, and eye loops clamped to the ends.
I believe a good strong fishing line would do fine, something rated high pound test. Since the z axis moves so slow, and travels the least, it's doubtful any friction would cause problems, and fishing line would slide smoothly.
I secured one end to the bolt extending through the brass z acme screw nut. The other end was zip tied to the bottom of the z carriage frame. Zip tied in honor of the assembly method of the 2 up ;)
Let me know if it works, or if you have any other ideas. Also, I can test the fishing line theory or try another more common material, I'm always up for experimentation.
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text:
If the qubd printers' flow rate is somewhat tuned, it should print no problem, without support. The lower guide bridges less than a quarter inch in the middle, so no problem there. I only got a strand or two slightly bowed on the edges of the rim since they only overhang about 1/16".
Basically it should print fine. I did have to drill a small hole in the side of the body to support the lower guide, but I've run for well over 100 hrs with no problems at all.
It's a lower profile than the large pulleys, just a bolt and screw needed. So it keeps the printer looking sleek. As for sag, I would say it eliminates 90% or more! I have an eye for things perpendicular, as an artist, and the tallest prints come out straight as a square can measure.
Hope it works well for you.

description.text: Crocodile... prints on its feet. There is designed in support under the belly and tail (...although his belly is only just off the ground)

Print with Raft but "No Support" as the support is designed in and should break away fairly easily from under the belly and tail. Use 3 shells on a Replicator 2 or 4 shells on a 5th generation Replicator and 35% infill to make sure the legs are strong and don't break when removing the support.
Take time and care to remove the support along the mouth so the randomised teeth are cleared away... just like a real croc's teeth!

This is a variation on the Mbot spool holder. I made my own before, but some of my spools were a little wider and would fall off. I liked the ridges on this one because it can accept varying spool widths. The original took a long time printing support material, so I trimmed one side flat so it can be printed without support material.

Print and enjoy. I think it has a flap to reduce stress on the hole in the panel. If this is so, you could mirror it for the other side. The one I created myself didn't have any I was using it fine for a long time.

A pot (without any bottomplate) made by using the Leap Motion controller and the Zpot program available in Airspace for Leap Motion.

Using the software zPots by ZeroUI made for the Leap Motion i tried to make a pot of my own design. Some faults came up... there's no bottom plate. But it's fun to see what you acctually can do by just using your hands. A little bit like the movie Minority Report.

This is a LHCP helical antenna for Inmarsat RX.
My antenna is based on the design I found at UHF-Satcom.com.
The upgrade I made are the mountings for the antenna itself and the helical wire part onto the reflector.

Details about the design can be found on my blog
http://diebastelkammer.wordpress.com/2014/09/21/helix-antenne-fur-parabolspiegel-um-inmarsat-zu-empfangen/
You need the following parts:
0,8 Aluminium sheet metal
2,5 Dia. solid wire
M3 Screws with nuts
SMA socket
printed parts

I was bored one Sunday, and was looking for a quick project. I found plans for a putt putt boat and started making it. Part way through, I realized the milk carton I cut in to a boat shape was no longer waterproof. I later cut a boat shape out of an old protein bottle. Long story short, I wanted a boat like the putt putt boat directions, so I designed one.

This can be printed with or without support material. If you print it with support material, only do exterior, because the inside would be hard to scoop out. I printed it without support material, but it required a little bit of cleanup inside and a little on the bow. I also printed it with 2 shells and 10% infill. To build the engine, the instructions can be found here:
http://www.sciencetoymaker.org/boat/ Once the engine is assembled, they can be fastened to the boat with a twist tie. It would also be a good idea to cover the straw hole and twist tie holes with some two part epoxy.
The tea light can be held in place with a loop of tape, or double sided tape.

With the new MK5 drive gears and smaller nozzles, the downward pressure has increased and so my old insulator retainers gave in one after another.
This is a simply/quick/easy fix for that. The baseholes are widened for the bolt heads so you can use the original hex bolts to connect it to the main extruder body. I know that the newer extruders have already solved this problem but as for me, I want use the old one as long as I can.

Print
Clear the holes if needed
Install

comments.text: I had a hybrid installed and that too failed (the plastic got between the outer shell and the PTFE and pushed the PTFE out)... Next I'm going to order a full PEEK one. I don't think that's going to fail easily. :)
comments.author: coasterman

comments.text: ouch... that does not sound good. If you don't print in PLA, then the full PEEK will be perfect. I used to use a peek, before upgrading to a peek/ptfe hybrid superpack for PLA, and that PEEK was probably the best ten bucks I spent on my bot.

This is a handy little clip to clip stuff on top of your Logitech G930 headphones. Some additional revisions will follow once its intended purpose is ready for printing, but this one is already perfectly usable. It's finished! New source file and versions with center guides added. Bonus internets for the first one to guess its intended purpose :-D

• Print
  • Glue/tape something onto it
  • Clip onto headphones
  • ???
  • Profit!
    • Enjoy :-) Remarks:
    -The normal versions have 1 additional mm of space, so you can use some foam tape for extra stability when on the headset.
    -Use a "No Padding" version if you don't want to use foam tape. The clip will still hold very well without padding, but might slip to the sides a bit if you fix a heavy object onto it. You can adjust the spacing in the sketch in the FreeCAD source file, the correct measure is commented in the file. Easy :-)
    -The "with center guides" versions do have small nibs on the top, acting as center guides for easy placement.
    -Prints well with 2 perimeters, 25% infill. Just make sure your slicer makes the springy arms solid.

Tank tracks are a remix of Thingiverse 163486. Tank tracks are redesigned to work with these sprockets and has a different track pitch of .775". Use brad nails (listed in instruction) to hold the track together. Tracks are 2" wide and I have tested them to hold up with Brushless motors and Lipo batteries printed at 30% fill. I tried 11 different design changes before finally getting these right and they hold up far better than I ever expected. It was a lot of fun trying to break them!
Tracks can be used with or without grouser bars. Grouser bars give excellent traction (except on smooth concrete!) and no metal contact with surface (unless you wear the grouser down to screw). There are holes in the flat surface of track to mount grousers.
Drive sprockets are designed to work with ServoCity .770" hubs. This should make it very easy to get drive motors, gears and shafts to run track.
You can design your own tank or see my things for all of the 3D printed suspension, gear boxes, idler wheels, frame rail drawings, body and electrical parts to build a complete tank from 1/8"x1 1/2" flat aluminum rails and metal angle brackets.
Some of the pictures have Vee's built into the track for traction, the tank just ripped them off. Grouser bars work much better and way more traction.
The tank in the picture has 90, 3D printed track segments, 45 per side.
There are two YouTube Videos of tank project. One video with dual Mabuchi RS540 motors controlled with Sabertooth 2x12. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dRz3TS2hO10
The other video is a 120 second gear box meltdown with Traxxas 38,800rpm Velineon 3500 brushless motors VXL-3s ESC and Dual 3S Lipo batteries, I figured the gearing I have, tank does about 11mph. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DlbDo2PSruk
The tracks hold up really well.
Just added a Tank Track that is 1.94" wide, same as remix track, so you can stay the same width if you have already started.
Also added a grouser drill guide to drill holes in track in the right place for grouser bars.
Update: There are more pictures of the tank and pictures of other projects at fastmiketanks.com.

Tank tracks will need raft and support. To put track together I used Home Depot Everbilt #15 x 1 1/2" wire brad nails. Drill the narrow ears to .076" #48 drill bit. Drill the wide ears to .073" # 49 drill bit. Push wire brad through and snip left over with dikes. Be careful not to split the ears with nail, or track will not hold up to abuse. Use different size bit if split. You will want to lightly file where ears mate to make them smoother running.
Drive sprocket A will need raft and full support. Drive sprocket B no raft or support. These are designed to use ServoCity .770" hubs with 6-32 socket head bolts.
Drive sprocket A is designed to use a pair of #216 o-rings on both sides of the gear for quieter running.
To make the tracks work smooth and with less effort, lay track down on table, roll the sprocket back and forth in the track, it will leave rub marks on the gear from nails. Lightly file those rub marks down with flat Nicholson hobby file until the gear lets go of the track smoothly. Take round file and clean up the nail slot in the gear. Only enough to get it to run nice and smooth.
Grouser bars will print without raft or support. You will want to drill the screw holes on the tank track to .093" #42 bit or 3/32" bit. Use #4 x 3/8" phillips pan head sheet metal screws to hold grousers to track.

description.text:
V2 update: The phone didn't fit as well as I wanted, so I've tuned up the demensions a bit for V2. The width is narrower by .100" and I reworked some of the fillets. Also enlarged the radius for the stem area to 1.5". I created this part to easily mount my phone on the stem of my road bike. I use it on the stationary trainer to easily listen to music while pedaling. This way I can crank tunes to keep my energy up without disturbing anybody. The cut-out to fit over the bike stem is a 1.5" radius. This would probably work on most stems and top tubes that are around an inch to two inches, with the use of a little padding to help a poor fit. If the fit is loose or slides easily on the frame mount or around the phone, you could try cutting a piece of old inner tube to stick in between for a better fit without having to modify the design at all or having to reprint it. My phone has the Seidio two-layer case (the one with the silicone glove plus the hard plastic outer shell), so the other standard Nexus S designs would never have enough room for it. This one should.
If you wanted to use it on the road or trail, it might (meaning definitely) need some better clamping mechanism on the phone. This design is for stationary applications. The pegs are to keep the zip ties separate to the mount won't flop around too much as you pedal, or move the bike on and off the trainer, etc. You could probably use it with some rubber bands to temporarily mount your phone to almost anything, like other gym equipment or something in your car or truck. Just zip-tie the thing to some part of your bike, and stick your phone in it. Happy pedaling!

Print the thing.

Scrape off the raft and supports (recommended, haven't tried it without them, YMMV).

Check the phone fit, use inner tube pieces to snug it up if needed.

Strap it to some part of your bike with zip-ties or big rubber bands. Could go vertically on the stem or horizontally on the bars.

Use some inner tube again to snug-up the fit on the stem, top tube or bars (if needed).

The pegs are there to make sure the zip ties or rubber bands stay put.

description.text:
This thing allows you to use a larger water container (whatever you choose) as long as you can put female 1/2 NPT (pipe thread) on it. Adapts 1/2 NPT to "soda bottle" threads like a 2 liter bottle has.
This object is a remix (combination) of 1/2" .5" NPT plug (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:210455) and thread creation exercise (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:333670).
It prints both with and without support on my reprap. Without support and brim was my best result.

This would be best printed with PLA. I printed it with ABS and it leaked. If ABS is used, print around 250 C, and expect lots of strings and webs. High temperatures are needed to get water tight prints with ABS.

OK, this customizable thing is near completion.
Defaults for each piece are 30mm diameter and 2mm tall, though these are adjustable parameters.
Defaults parameters for the grid are now 4 rows and 5 columns, for a total of 18 pieces ( rows x columns minus one for every even counted row). I also tightened the inter-piece space to 0.02*diameter from 0.05, which should also these 18 pieces to be printed on my Flash Forge with 4"x6" print bed.
It will create a grid of separated flat game pieces. The grid is hexagonal, self-centering, and symmetrical in both X and Y, which should allow for the maximum number of pieces to be printed, though this means the number of columns will be different for odd and even rows (unlike a square grid).
Just flat surfaces now, no textures at this time.

description.text:
This is a stand/bracket designed to help you digitalizing your negatives and diapos. It's made to keep your negatives frame in the correct position, regardless of brand or size.
I use it with lomography's digitalizer, (110mm, 35mm and 120mm frames) but it will work with any digitalizing frame.
I'm working in a laser cut frame too, so I will publish it as soon as I've finished it.
It's made in 3mm translucent white acrylic.

Designed in Corel Draw, cut it with laser in a 3mm translucent white acrylic.
To digitalize:
1- Mount the stand and prepare your negatives inside the frame.
2- Put a intense white light (better LED light) behind the stand.
3- Put your frame in the shelf of the stand.
4- Use a Macro lens (better up to 80mm) to take a close framing photo of each negative. I use my tripod and the remote control to have a good stabilization.
5- Use any RAW software (Ex: Adobe Camera RAW) to inver your negative.
To learn how to invert the negatives I used this references:
http://petapixel.com/2013/03/25/digitizing-your-film-using-your-dslr/
http://petapixel.com/2012/05/18/how-to-scan-film-negatives-with-a-dslr/

title: adpater to use 50mm fan on 40mm mount.

description.text: I found a high flow fan so i replaced a 40mm low from with this adapter plate.  I used M3 12mm cap screws to mount the plate to the existing housing then m3 13 phillips heads to mount the fan to the adapter.

Print with very low infill and 2 perimeters if you need to keep the weight down.
I printed with 60% infill and 3 perimeters so the weight would help cantilever the duct and hold it up off the prints. the adapter has nut traps so you have to drill out the thin divider on the 50mm holes. Put nuts in the trap before you mount the adapter to your duct. they will not fit once it is mounted.
mount adapter to duct then mount fan to adapter, enjoy high air flow...

title: An enclosure for using the Arduino Nano as IR transmitter controlled over USB

description.text: An enclosure for using an Arduino Nano as an IR-transmitter controlled over USB. Check out my project on GitHub for the software and build instructions: https://github.com/robertmoro/MagicLightingRemote. The top has optional holes that fit two magnets. I have included some model variations. For the top: with magnets on the inside, the outside and no magnets. For the main part: with and without a LED-hole. The OpenSCAD file is included to make your own variations. The text 'FTEK' is added to the case top by importing the STL-file into www.tinkercad.com and then adding the text.
Select a main and top part from the various variations and print them. Use four 20 x 2 mm bolts and nuts to hold the parts together. The magnets are 20 mm in diameter and 2 mm thick.

description.text: This is a half scale model of my version of the furnace part of a gas fired Gingery-style crucible furnace for melting metals. I was trying to wrap my head around the assembly / proportions / through-holes, so I put together an exploded model. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/k2j0fnVuxWs

In real life, once cast in refractory cement, these parts just stack on top of each other and gravity does the rest.  A crucible is set on top of the plinth (in yellow).  Gas flame enters through the hole in the side, forming a vortex around the crucible which melts the metal.  
Later, I may put together the supporting and lifting framework just to have an idea of how the complete furnace is assembled.
If you decide to use this as a scale model to construct your own crucible furnace, it would be polite to purchase a copy of Mr. Gingery's book.

description.text: I first created the 8bit Zombie for a video game back in 2008. Since then the image has been translated into a variety of formats. Here it is now in 2014 as a 3d print.  This is the first in a series of 8bit inspired creatures that I'm thinking about releasing as miniatures for roleplaying and other fantasy tabletop games. #jvs3d #blackbirdandpeacock

I used Photoshop to create the original 8bit image. I then translated the image into a vector so I could extrude it in a 3d program. Saving the extruded design as a .STL I could then resize, duplicate and move around the image in Makerware in preparation for printing. This model needs no rafts or supports. The .Thing is saved at 3" tall and 5/8" thick. I printed the 8bit Zombie in Glow in the Dark PLA on a Replicator 2.

I also use the 30pin to lightning adaptor and put layers of tap around the connector to get a secure fit. description.text: Mod for QAV250 so that cam is angled 10 degrees up for fast forward flight. Just print and mount and fly! :)

Rigidbot waterproof  24v led Mount and rails.  The corner rails can be printed on a rigidbot big.  You will need to print two top rails to make the led holder top rail and use the coupler in the center to connect them together.  I used DC24V 5M 300leds 72W IP65 Glue Waterproof RGBW leds to mount on the rails and a bunch up clips to prevent the led strip from lifting off the rail.

The side rail will hold two 165mm led segments and the top rail will hold 3 led 165mm segment.
LEDS used:
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/DC24V-5M-300leds-72W-IP65-Glue-Waterproof-RGBW-12-14lm-led-Led-SMD5050-Tap-Light/2014360222.html
Led Controller used:
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/LED-RGB-White-Controller-LED-Wireless-IR-Remote-RGBW-Lamps-Mini-Controller-control-remote-RF104/1936402571.html
LED Cable used:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/181465286703?_trksid=p2059210.m2749.l2649&var=480430568477&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT Connectors used to make the cables :
http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?lang=en&site=us&keywords=SAM1112-32-ND+&x=21&y=12
Connectors used to plug the cable into. Mounts on the rail end.
http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?lang=en&site=us&keywords=SAM1117-32-ND+&x=0&y=0
Use 1/2 inch shrink tubing on cable ends
To solder on led connector peel back the waterproof coating on the LED end and use some tape to hold it out of the way while you solder the connector. Slightly bend the pins on the connector so they are close to the center of the LED solder pads. It might be necessary to trim the connector leads if they are to long. Once you finished soldering remove the tape and the waterproof coating should pop back into place.
I used 12 clips to hold the led strip in place for each of the top rails and 7 clips for each of the side rails. You will need two brackets for each side and top rails and two coupler brackets for the two top rails.

I made this for my Thunder Tiger Atlantic Motor Yacht, is an electric rc boat, but I am sure you can fit it in any boat of similar size (25" to 35"). Just print it. I used:
3D Density = Medium (20%)
Shells = Normal
Layer High = 0.3
Supports = No
Raft = No
Once you print it, drill a hole in the middle of the antenna and use a servo screw to attach to the base. BTW The antenna is 80 mm long. My white filament looks a bit "yellowish", so I will paint it later.

description.text: This cam mount is designed to have a Fatshark 600tvl camera screwed to it.  Has mounting holes to utilize the existing camera case screws. New reliefs for the PAL/NTSC jumper and Power/Video connector have also been added.

These Tank Idler wheels are made to go with the Tank Track 2in and Idler arms in my things. They will work with other tracks on Thingiverse also.
These are the main Idler rollers that hold the Tank Track in place and support the weight of tank. The stubs space them out to the right distance from tank side rail. These are made to use 1/4" x 3/8" x 1/8" sealed ball bearings and 1/4" x 1 1/2" shoulder bolts (stripper bolts). They place idlers at 1 1/2" center from the side rail, perfect for mounting track. Use (4) #212 National o-rings on idlers to make them run smother and quieter on track.
See the worm gear case and idler arms for drill guide PDF download of frame drilling. I will usually have frame rail kits on eBay. Update October 2016: Uploaded a few more idler wheels to choose from. O-Rings are kind of expensive when you need a lot of them. There is a 2 O-Ring Idler roller and a Blank one with no O-Ring grooves. Update December, 2017: Just downloaded some mag wheel type tank track idler wheels in bigger sizes. Please see my things for tank related parts

Print with raft and support. It is tricky but take a 3/8" drill bit and ream out the bearing holes by hand. Go in slowly until it hits the bearing stop and pull out. Press the bearings in holes. Bearings are 1/4" shaft x 3/8" OD x 1/8" wide. Can find them on ebay. Use 1/4" x 1 1/2" shoulder bolts and 10-24 nuts. You can file them down where they roll in the track if hitting the track links. Will work with tracks that have a .350" inside between track links.

description.text:
Made this after I fixed the belt connection to my bed and then broke the original Rework tensioner. This is a bit more heavy duty.  
5/5/2015--Update: Uploaded a new version of the 608 Bearing block, it now has captive holes for the 3mm nuts used to tension the bock.

You will need:  
2 M3 x 40 mm bolts/screws (I tried 60mm long at first, but those hit the belt)  
2 M3 washers  
2 M3 nuts  
1 608 bearing  
1 M8 bolt 30 mm or longer  
1 M8 washer  
1 M8 Nut  
Use the two M3 Screws to tighten the tension.

author: Danf

title: Z Axis Extender Kit for Makerbot Cupcake

description.text: Pop your top and lift your lid with this Z axis extension kit. I can print up to 205mm so far, and it can probably be tweaked to go higher. (Now that I have it installed I realize that I could add another 10mm to the base) This was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4261 and the pulley mounted crank from that settup works great with this. I've added .obj files for those who want to stretch things a bit more...

I found the easiest was to install was to unscrew the top of the Makerbot and lift the whole lot up.  Remove the lower Z axis retainers and screw the four base towers in.  The top lifters should be installed as per the top.  I included a few extra screw holes in case you think you need extra bracing. Note that one of the lower parts has some print support to cut out. The top lifters are adjustable so you can raise it or lower it to the capabilities of your machine.  You can also lift the Z axis pulleys to the tops of the rods to get a little extra height out.

title: 3D Printed TV Fractal Antenna with Wall Mount

description.text:
A 3D printable dipole TV antenna that only requires plain wire, one end of a coax cable, and a few machine screws.
It's not great, but I'm not an RF engineer so I'd love to hear suggestions on improvements (and if I have enough motivation I'll maybe even implement them :). Depending on orientation and use/placement of a balun and tin foil reflector, it gets me three channels from one repeater station and four from another repeater in my rural area. All channels in my area are the new digital type.
The TV antenna fractal pattern was borrowed from William Rucker's instructable:
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-make-a-fractal-antenna-for-HDTV-DTV-plus-/?ALLSTEPS
The 4:1 coax balun design was determined from this balun calculator: http://n-lemma.com/calcs/dipole/balun.htm
The center frequency is purported to be 554 MHz (I have not verified this).

Parts list:
  • Wire. (I used 24 AWG solid core wire. You can see on the picture some has insulation, and some does not - it's not important, whatever fits best.)
  • x8 1/2" #4 machine screws and nuts.
  • x4 1" #4 machine screws and nuts.
  • x4 sheet rock screws (for screwing the mount to the wall).
  • Optional: Additional x4 1" #4 machine screws for wall mount (I used foam tape and it seems to be working great).
  • Optional: A 4:1 balun. (AKA an impedance matching transformer, like the one from Radio Shack in the instructable. It may provide better results with than the coax balun I made up. No local Radio Shack where I live, so I made my own.)
    There may be some holes missing in the 3D designs that you might have to drill by hand - it was a work in progress, and I didn't go back and add screw holes for connecting things that were drawn up later. I may fix this later as I would like to print an antenna for a second bedroom TV.
    Steps:
    1) 3D print the parts.
    2) Cut the wire and follow the fractal pattern printed (see the instructable for more info). Use screws to hold the wire in place and to make the connections. Tape or glue can help keep the wires in the tracks.
    3) Attach the panel-side of the wall mount to hold the two sides together. I used foam tape - you could also drill through the antenna panel and use screws.
    4) If using a coax balun, cut your spare coax cable so there's enough length for the RF connector to reach the TV from where you intend to mount your antenna to your TV. I went for about 5 feet. Otherwise, make sure you have a working and intact coax cable with RF connectors on both ends.
    5) If you are using a home-made coax balun:
    a.) Cut a 7" length of coax. Strip back about 1/4' to 3/8" on both ends, including enough of the dielectric material to get a good connection on the center conductor.
    b.) Connect the coax balun to the dipole centers following this design: http://n-lemma.com/calcs/dipole/balun.htm . The "antenna feed point" should connect to the dipole center conductors. This is the black loop in the middle of the antenna in the picture.
    c.) Use screws and wire to connect the coax balun to the coax cable attachment points at the bottom of the panels. I attached the balun very near to the dipole centers, and then ran wire down to the coax cable connection points.
    d.) Strip the cut end of the coax cable back about 1-2". Screw these connections down to the coax cable connection points on the bottom of the panel. It will be a weak point here until you screw down the coax antenna strain relief. Use two of the printed strain reliever halves and four 1" #4 screws to clamp the coax cable in place.
    5) If you are using a store-bought impedance matcher:
    -> Follow the instructions from the instructable. You may or may not want to use the coax cable clamp - up to you to figure out since I didn't use this approach. ;-)
    6) At this point, your panel is mostly made. If you want the wall mount, use a wooden 5/16" dowel (or print one). Force it down from the top through the hinge points on both sides of the wall mount.
    7) Use sheetrock screws to attach the mount to the wall.
    8) Enjoy a few channels :)
    Still somewhat in utero, but it does work. It may not work any better than a coat hanger, but it makes for a better conversational piece!

author: bradnelson

title: Printrbot compatable LCD Display with case.

description.text: This is my schematic, board layout file, bezel and back stl files for my Printrbot Simple Metal LCD Display. This should work with any 3D printer that uses Rev-D of the printrboard with thier firmware. I discussed this on their forums But printrbot has taken them down... I have left the link here in case the wayback machine archived it...( http://help.printrbot.com/Answers/View/9702/What+LCDs+work+with+the+Printrboard+Rev.+D#answer9885 ) Basic board build can be seen on my blog - AT THIS LINK See the instructions for more details. THIS BEZEL WILL NOT FIT THE OFFICIAL PRINTRBOT LCD

Manufacture the board as laid out. Build with all components on the back of the board except the rotary encoder and LCD. Attach Standard 20x4 LCD directly to the base board with header soldered on both sides. Printed washers are to act as spacers between the LCD board and the manufactured board. Completed board assembly should fit into the bezel, add the back with M3x18 screws.
Enjoy

This design was made by New American Public Art as a part of the Unknown Territory Fellowship at The Hacktory in Philadelphia.

The dodecahedron is always our test subject for experiments because of its unruly math and quality to compound errors. In this instance it was used to developed some snap together tech. We used .22" cast acrylic for most of the iterations, but found that wood also functions moderately well with the same design.
The basics of the snap tech are included with the final design. With instructions on how to adjust the design for material thickness. This design was made by New American Public Art as a part of the Unknown Territory Fellowship at The Hacktory in Philadelphia.

title: Tank Track, Shocks, Idler Arm, Pins

description.text:
This was quite a learning experience. Hard to print and a lot of work to make everything fit. But I dropped a 7 1/2 lbs tank from 24" on to my table several times without breaking anything. May take a couple times making shocks, but they will hold up nicely and give your tank a nice cushion to ride on.
This stuff goes with the Tank Track 2in, Tank Track Idler wheels, worm gear cases, body parts, and lots more in my things.
If you space the Idler arms and shocks 3 inches apart on your tank side rail, you can make your tank as long as you want. All of the parts are spaced so the tank track has a center 1.5 inches from the side rail. 2 inch tank track gives 1/2" clearance to tank side rail.
Parts you will need besides the printed parts. (4) 1/4"x3/8"x1/8" sealed ball bearings, (8) #212 O-rings for idlers, (1) 1/4"x1 1/2" shoulder bolt, (1) 1/4"x7/8" shoulder bolt, (1) 1/4"x3/4" shoulder bolt, (1) 1/4"x1/2" shoulder bolt, (4) 10-24 nuts, (1) 4x3/8" sheet metal screw, (1) #6 flat washer, (1) #90 Hillman compression spring 1/2"x3/4"x.035 (optional), (1) #6 Hillman compression spring 5/16"x1 1/2"x.020, for each of these suspension units. Springs, bolts available at True Value or Fastenal.
Added some additional sizes of Idler arms and shocks to play with. Can choose from 2 1/2" 2 1/4" and 2" arms. Shocks are 3", 2 3/4" and 2 1/2" eye to eye. #6 springs are for the longest shocks, use the same size spring only shorter for other shocks. Shorter arms will be able to make roller closer than 3" apart and shorter shocks will drop tank height. Have fun! There is a PDF drill guide for the frame rails in the downloads, also other drill guides for gear boxes in the gear box listing. Be sure to check out the instructions tab for more info. Dec. 8, 2017: I just downloaded some sprockets and cool mag idler wheels in bigger sizes to play with. Also some different arms that hold the track idlers on the arm. See my things for more tank related stuff. Dec. 29, 2017: Have CNC machined motor rails available to help you build a tank. This is the hardest part to make on the tank, having one will make it much easier. For more pictures of the fastmiketank1 project and pictures of my latest projects go to fastmiketanks.com

On all of the shoulder bolts, if you want it to move or swing drill the 3D printed part it goes in with an "F" (.257") drill bit. If you want it tight like the 1/4"x7/8" shoulder bolt on Idler arm for Idler wheel use a 1/4" (.250") drill bit.
Print Idler arms with raft and support, file down to fit the frame. Slack here will let the arms and tracks bow out.
Shocks, what can I say these are a challenge to build! Have to use every kind of support you can and they may still not build. Make sure you have a good bead on bed to start. These can come lose if not stuck to bed really well. As it gets higher it will pull on the shock moving and has more leverage the higher up it gets. Try spinning 90 degrees or moving back on bed. Drill holes for shock pin and file down to fit. I made it tight on the arm and move on the shock bottom.
Okay now comes the fun part. For these shocks to work I had to drill out the inside of the bottom of the shock. Start with a "D" bit then go to a "E" bit then "F" bit until it moves freely up and down in the shock top. File down anything sticking out on the outside of lower shock tube. You may have to assemble shock bottom on arm to hold it to drill. Go easy or you will break the shock.
The #6 Hillman spring fits right inside top shock. If you have a heavier tank add the #90 springs to the bottom of shock. You can control how much movement and load capability by the springs wire size and length. The #6 spring fits this tanks weight and travel requirements. You can trim the spring or get different wire sizes to fine tune your tanks suspension. I gave my tank a little more travel and stiffness in the front to take up any impact and let the back ride like a boat. But the more evenly you spread the tanks weight out on the track the better the tank will be able to go over bumps smoothly and be able to climb hills.
Be sure that when you mount the arm, the angle of the shock has free movement at the pivot points for the full range of motion of the arm.
Pins, print with raft no support.

description.header: NEWS: Version 2 released! See below for details.

description.text:
This is a slim line case for the Beaglebone Black development board that was developed with the following goals in mind:
-Minimize volume and plastic used
-Expose all eternal ports
-Expose pin headers for development
-Code with OpenSCAD for easy modification
-Tight tolerances to secure board when moving around
-Include pin header diagram that can print on standard shipping labels See instruction section for printing and label details The OpenSCAD source files are attached and can be used to modify the case with options at the top of the file. The library file is a good reference for board dimensions in other projects.

1-23-15: Version 2 OpenSCAD files posted
Cleaned up the OpenSCAD files and posted them to the source files list. The Beaglebone dimension constants were moved to an external library file to help clean up the main code file. If you want to make your own BBB accessory you might find this useful and save yourself a bunch of work! 12-30-14: Version 2 released!
Updated based on my experience carting the case around in my backpack for three months.
  • Thickened the wall slightly for better rigidity
  • Strengthened the tabs that secure the lid for better grip and to help prevent snapping off during case abuse.
  • Added extra area to the bottom of the board pegs to prevent snapping off after excessive use.
  • Used a better library for creating the rounded corners that should make for smoother slicing
  • Moved all of the dimension constants from the main OpenSCAD file to a library file to help code readability.
    • 9-22-14: Added dimensionally accurate pin header labels!
    Thanks to my amazing wife for creating this. See instructions for info

The case does not require any external hardware at this time. The case shown was printed on a Lulzbot Taz 4 and sliced with Slic3r using the following settings:
2 Perimeters
2 Solid Layers top and bottom
30% infill
Green PLA at 190C

The board tolerances are tight to securely hold the board in place while carrying around. This works great for the majority of users but in a few cases when a printer slightly over extrudes or is printed with a material that requires large perimeters then the beaglebone may be a bit too snug. Two options are to either reduce perimeter extrusion width or print at 102% scale. Both have been reported to work by different users.

The included label PDF file is made to print on Avery 4"x2" shipping labels that can be found at any office supply or department store. The label spacing is 0.1" to physically match the locations of the pins. Just print, cut, and line up.

You will need both the base scad file and the library file in the same directory to work. The base scad file has several options at the top to modify what model is generated. The settings and their effects are listed in the comments.  
The scad files are provided open source so feel free to modify and borrow from as you wish. The library file is useful if you would like a pre-created list of all Beaglebone Black dimensions. If you do use my code for other projects a link back or reference is always appreciated but not necessary. I love to see what other can build from my work!

title: Model Airplane Wheel Hub for 6mm Shaft

description.text: Hub for mounting the tire from a set of foam or rubber model airplane wheels to a 6mm shaft.

Additional hardware required for each hub:
  • 4 #6-32 square nuts
  • 3 #6-32 machine screws to mount an outer plate, either 1" or 1.25".
  • 1 #6-32 set screw. I used a 3/8" one.
  • An outer plate to sandwich the tire.
    • After printing, carefully remove all the support from inside the nut slots and insert the square nuts. Once they're aligned, I recommend plugging the slots so they can't slide back out; I used hot glue for this. Slide the hub on the shaft and then insert and tighten the set screw. To remove the model airplane tire from the hub it comes with, you can slide a couple thin pieces of metal between the hub and tire and work it off like using tire levers on a bicycle tire. Once you have the tire, slide it on the mounted hub and position the outer plate and machine screws. You made need to squeeze the tire between the hub and the plate before you can get the threads on the screw mating with the nut. After assembly, make sure that the wheel is true; if the wheel needs truing simply tighten or loosen the nearest machine screw. For my outer plates, I cut some polycarbonate with a hole saw and then drilled holes for the machine screws to pass through. If requested, I can make a simple outer plate STL to be printed.

Our throat plate on the bandsaw got chewed up by a misaligned blade.  Ginned up a replacement.

Designed to use 4mm plywood (1/8" may be acceptable).
Other than that cut it and install.

These work great! Just fill with cooking oil up to about half inch to the inside riser and your ready to go. No more ants messing up your feeders.  
It prints with an 1/8 inch hole all the way thru, which makes cutting 5 inches of coat hanger to press right in. Mine was a bit tight but that's what i wanted. If your's is loose fitting you may want to fill the gap so ants can't get down through the hole. 5 inched leaves for about 1/2 inch hook, you can make yours longer if like. Depends on how you plan to hang the feeder. Also just make a tiny bind in wire towards the bottom to keep the oil bowl from sliding all the way down.  
I printed mine with only 2 layers and 20% fill and then painted with acrylic hobby paint and they are working great. PLA plastic.  
Hope you enjoy, it's that time of year when hummers are real active and ants everywhere.  
Thanks, Rick.  
UPDATE:  Paint at least two coats of paint and if you have oil base paint i think it will do even better. Mine last summer want to seep out a little. I need to get mine in from this years winter! Been out there the whole season of cold weather. Hasn't hurt it, though need to get it ready for this spring. Have fun, and happy hummer season, when it gets here.  :)

description.text:
The RigidBot Tool Caddy is designed to fit on the lower frame of the RigidBot, while holding various tools used frequently in 3D printing. The example photo shows cutters, needle nose pliers, a pen, angled tweezers, straight tweezers, and two allen wrenches.
Inspired by bobnojio's original RigidBot Tool Caddy, this version has been adapted to hold larger items, including the cutters and pliers. Tools pictured in the example and guaranteed to fit with this holder:
  • 13cm straight and curved tweezers
  • Diagonal cutting pliers
  • Needle nose pliers
  • Two allen wrenches for your 3D printer
  • Generic pen
Print using your choice of materials and slide onto the lower RigidBot frame. This caddy is designed to sit over the frame rail and side panel.

title: RichRap 3DR RAMPS 1.4 mount using 8MM threaded rod and M8 nut

description.text: This is an alternate way to mount a RAMPS 1.4/Arduino Mega 2650 board to the RichRap 3DR using the 8mm threaded rod and M8 nuts for the spool holder instead of the 3mm stand-offs in the electronics mount which were weak and didn't fit the M3 bolts I had. This is a much simpler way to mount the RAMPS since it's just one M8 nut and it gives your clearance to access your USB port and power port.

Printed with support material, drilled out the 8mm hole and the M3 bolt holes with a drill to make sure the bolts and rod fit. Place an M8 nut, then mount the Arduino mega, then thread the rod through the M8 nut.

description.text:
I made a custom enclosure for my RepRap i3 and needed a spool holder that would work with it. It should work well with just about any cabinet/enclosure, just needs a few holes cut.
There are several pieces to assemble:
  • end caps that work with spools that have a 48mm hole, like the SainSmart spools
  • the main mount plate
  • the top support hooks
  • the rod backing piece
    The two end caps are designed to have a 608ZZ bearing pressed in and to be slid on to either 8mm smooth rod (what I used) or 8M threaded rod if you want to use a nut to secure the spool.
    The two side hooks slide into the slots on the main mount plate which creates an L shape that will hold on to the edge of a cabinet. The ends of the hook pieces have a 'hook' so that you can cut a 25mm x 7mm slot in your cabinet that they will hold on to.
    The backing piece slides over the 8mm rod and pushes into the main plate. It is somewhat optional. If your cabinet is wood or metal you probably won't need it.
